data.title: Fanfare (1958)
data.meta_description: In the small Dutch village of Lagerheide, two members of the local brass band get into a fight, forcing the band to be split in two. The two hotheads and their followers are doing their utmost to sabotage each other’s attempts at becoming the band who will represent the village at the upcoming brass band competition.
data.text:
"Did you hear what that pig has done now?"

"I thought it was a cow, wasn't it?"

In the fictional village of Lagewierde (shot in the actual Dutch town Giethoorn) there are more waterways than roads. This draws a lot of tourists, who can get a refreshing drink in one of the two establishments in the village. A man called Krijns owns a cafe next to the lake and the pub in the centre of the village is owned by a man called Geursen.

Krijns and Geursen can't stand each other! Which is kind of a problem, because they're playing together in the same brass band ("Kunst en Vriendschap", which translates to "Art and Friendship"). The arguments gets ever heavier,…

An incredible way to begin a film, with a horn bringing forth cows, as though floating toward an animated trail of pie-scent; and such a way to end one: two disparate musics in fact one music, and for all the squabbling of men it is God – it is the composer – who can align those who find between each other meaningless dispute. To be laughed at is unpleasant, it has been said. Humiliation appears to be the primary motivation of all serious political action ever taken. If we were to squeeze this innocent, pastoral picture into the mould of Political Commentary – if we were to make the peevish swan in the Rijksmuseum Holland itself – then perhaps there…
